questions.text: A teenager is brought to the ER with symptoms of increased confusion and lethargy. Lab tests reveal abnormal liver function and significantly elevated serum ammonia levels. His parents note his recent high protein intake, attributed to his athletic activities. Hyperammonemia can disrupt the TCA cycle by depleting a specific intermediate, leading to impaired energy metabolism. Which TCA cycle intermediate is most likely depleted in this scenario, contributing to the cycle's inhibition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) α-ketoglutarate  

 

Option C:

 

 

  • Since ammonia is toxic to CNS, it is important to maintain only traces (10-20 μg/dL) in peripheral blood and it should be effectively detoxified and eliminated from the body.
  • In severely impaired hepatic function or the development of collateral links between the portal and systemic veins in cirrhosis, portal blood bypasses the liver, systemic blood ammonia may attain toxic levels.
  • Symptoms of ammonia intoxication include tremor, slurred speech, blurred vision, coma, and ultimately death.
  • Ammonia may be toxic to the brain in part because it reacts with α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate.
  • The resulting depletion of levels of α-ketoglutarate then impairs function of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle in neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

Option A. Aspartate:  Although aspartate is involved in the urea cycle, its depletion does not directly inhibit the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Malate:  Malate is a TCA cycle intermediate, but it is not directly depleted by hyperammonemia.

 

Option D. Fumarate:  Fumarate is also part of the TCA cycle but is not the intermediate depleted by hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperammonemia can inhibit the TCA cycle by depleting α-ketoglutarate. Ammonia is detoxified in the liver by the urea cycle, which consumes α-ketoglutarate as it combines with ammonia to form glutamate. This process depletes α-ketoglutarate, a critical intermediate in the TCA cycle, leading to impaired energy metabolism and contributing to the symptoms observed.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 291, 292, Lippincott: P 253.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child, while playing, accidentally ingests a small amount of rat poison containing fluoroacetate, found in the cupboard. This substance reacts with oxaloacetate to produce fluorocitrate. Which major metabolic pathway is most likely to be inhibited by this poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TCA Cycle

 

Option D:

 

  • TCA Cycle is inhibited by Fluoroacetate, is an e.g., of suicidal inhibition.
  • Fluoroacetate first gets converted to Fluoroacetyl coA → condenses with Oxaloacetate → converted to Fluoro citrate → inhibit Aconitase enzyme of TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETC: Inhibitors includes Alkylguanides, hypotensive drug, Rotenone, insecticide and fish poison, Barbiturates, Carboxin, BAL, Naphthoquinone etc.

 

Option B. Glycolysis: Key enzymes such as HK, GK, PFK are inhibited by G-6-P, Glucagon, ATP, cyclic AMP, citrate, low pH, cAMP.

 

Option C. HMP shunt: G6PD is the rate-limiting step, inhibited by NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorocitrate, formed from the reaction of fluoroacetate with oxaloacetate, is a potent inhibitor of the TCA cycle. It specifically inhibits aconitase, an enzyme in the TCA cycle, thereby blocking the conversion of citrate to isocitrate and disrupting cellular energy production.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 161-163.

choices.text: Pantothenic Acid as a part of CoA

questions.text:
There are one specific vitamins, which is involved in the TCA cycle as key for comprehending its biochemical intricacies and the nutritional requirements that support this fundamental metabolic pathway.

 

Which of the following vitamins are involved in the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

All the listed vitamins are involved in the TCA cycle:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pantothenic Acid:  It is a component of Coenzyme A (CoA), essential for the formation of Acetyl-CoA, a substrate entering the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: It is converted into Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD), a coenzyme used by succinate dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Thiamine:  As thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), it is a coenzyme for the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate into Acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis with the TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamins in TCA Cycle:
 

  • Pantothenic Acid as a part of CoA
  • Riboflavin as FAD
  • Thiamine
  • Niacin as NAD+

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 251.

questions.text: Which enzyme catalyzes the substrate-level phosphorylation step in the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA synthetase

 

Option C:

 

Formation of succinate:

 

  • The enzyme is succinate thiokinase / Succinyl-CoA Synthetase (step 5 of TCA cycle).
  • A molecule of GDP is phosphorylated to GTP and succinate is formed.
  • The GTP can be converted to ATP by reacting with an ADP molecule:

                                      GTP + ADP → GDP + ATP

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Isocitrate dehydrogenase- Catalyzes step 3 of TCA cycle.

 

Option B: α- ketoglutarate dehydrogenase - Catalyzes step 4 of TCA cycle.

 

Option C: Succinate dehydrogenase- Catalyzes step 6 of TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Succinyl CoA synthetase catalyzes the only substrate-level phosphorylation step within the TCA cycle, where GDP (guanosine diphosphate) is phosphorylated to GTP (guanosine triphosphate), which can then be converted to ATP. This step involves the conversion of succinyl CoA to succinate.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 247-249.

questions.text: During the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate in the TCA cycle, several reactions occur, leading to the production of energy-rich molecules. This conversion involves the decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate, the generation of Succinyl CoA, and the subsequent formation of succinate. how many ATP molecules are typically produced through this series of reactions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3.5

 

Explanation:

 

The conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate in the TCA cycle involves two key steps:

  1. First, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate to form succinyl-CoA, CO₂, and NADH.
    • The NADH produced in this step will yield approximately 2.5 ATP molecules when oxidized through the electron transport chain.
  2. Second, succinyl-CoA synthetase (also called succinate thiokinase) catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate with the generation of GTP (which is energetically equivalent to ATP.
    • This substrate-level phosphorylation directly produces 1 GTP/ATP molecule.

 

Therefore, the total ATP yield from converting α-ketoglutarate to succinate is:

  • 2.5 ATP from NADH oxidation in the electron transport chain
  • 1 ATP from substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP formation)
  • Total: 3.5 ATP molecules 

 

This makes option C (3.5) the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the energetics of the TCA cycle reactions, specifically:

  • The α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex reaction produces NADH
  • The succinyl-CoA synthetase reaction produces GTP/ATP via substrate-level phosphorylation
  • NADH yields approximately 2.5 ATP when oxidized through the electron transport chain
  • Together, these reactions yield 3.5 ATP molecules from the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate

questions.text: Acetyl CoA plays a central role in energy metabolism, acting as a substrate for several biosynthetic pathways. Which of the following is NOT a product of Acetyl CoA conversion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Options A:

 

Acetyl CoA cannot be converted into glucose because the pyruvate dehydrogenase reaction that produces Acetyl CoA from pyruvate is irreversible. This means that organisms that rely solely on acetyl CoA as a substrate for gluconeogenesis cannot convert fatty acids into glucose. This process is known as the irreversibility of fatty acid to glucose conversion.

 

Explanation:

 

Options B: Fatty acids can be synthesized from acetyl CoA in a process known as lipogenesis, primarily in the liver and adipose tissue.

 

Options C: Cholesterol is also synthesized from acetyl CoA via the mevalonate pathway, which is critical for cell membrane integrity and as a precursor for steroid hormones.

 

Options D: Ketone bodies are produced from acetyl CoA during periods of low carbohydrate availability, such as fasting, prolonged exercise, or low-carbohydrate diets, primarily in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acetyl CoA is not a substrate for gluconeogenesis.
  • It is the starting material for Fatty acid and Cholesterol synthesis.
  • It is an intermediate in Ketone body synthesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p188, 189

questions.text: In a fitness center, a personal trainer discusses with a client the metabolic changes that occur during intense aerobic workouts. The trainer explains how the body metabolizes glucose to meet the increased energy demands of vigorous exercise. The conversation leads to a question about the form in which carbon atoms from glucose enter the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle during such high-energy activities. What is the correct form in which these carbons enter the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetyl-CoA   

 

Option C:

 

During aerobic glycolysis, the end product, pyruvate, is converted into acetyl-CoA before entering the TCA cycle. Acetyl-CoA then combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate, which is the first compound formed in the cycle. Thus, the carbons derived from glucose primarily enter the TCA cycle in the form of acetyl-CoA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Citrate: Oxaloacetate condenses with acetyl CoA entering TCA cycle to form citrate (a tricarboxylic molecule) (inside TCA cycle) with the help of the enzyme citrate synthase.

 

Option B. Oxaloacetate: Pyruvate is carboxylated to oxaloacetate which is then used for gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. Pyruvate: Glucose is converted to pyruvate which is then converted to acetyl-CoA → enter TCA cycle and Pyruvate as such cannot enter TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In aerobic glycolysis, glucose is converted into pyruvate → then converted to Acetyl-CoA, which actually enters the citric acid cycle. 
  • Two Acetyl-CoA, each containing two of the glucose’s carbons, are formed from each glucose molecule.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 96-98.

choices.text: Pyruvate condenses with Oxaloacetate to form Citrate
Alpha ketoglutarate is a five Carbon compound
Oxidative Phosphorylation occurs in the cytoplasm only
Krebs cycle can operate in anaerobic condition

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Krebs Cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha ketoglutarate is a five Carbon compound.

 

Option B:

 

Alpha-ketoglutarate, indeed, is a five-carbon compound that is part of the Krebs Cycle. It is formed from isocitrate through a decarboxylation reaction catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase and is further converted into succinyl-CoA, a four-carbon compound, in a subsequent step of the cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pyruvate does not directly condense with oxaloacetate to form citrate. Instead, pyruvate is first converted into acetyl-CoA, which then condenses with oxaloacetate.

 

Option C: Oxidative phosphorylation occurs in the mitochondria, not in the cytoplasm.

 

Option D: The Krebs cycle is an aerobic process and does not operate under anaerobic conditions, as it relies on oxygen indirectly through the electron transport chain for the regeneration of NAD+.

 

Educational Objective:

 

α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase:

 

  • α-ketoglutarate (5C) oxidised and decarboxylated to Succinyl CoA (4C)
  • Second Oxidative Decarboxylation
  • 1 NADH is formed
  • Physiologically Unidirectional step
  • Multienzyme Complex similar to Pyruvate Dehydrogenase

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p161-167.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is known to bind to CoA and condense with oxaloacetate, thereby inhibiting the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluoroacetate.

 

Option C:

 

  • The poison fluoroacetate is found in some of plants.
  • Some fluorinated compounds are used as anticancer agents and industrial chemicals (including pesticides) are metabolized to fluoroacetate
  • It is toxic because Fluoroacetyl-CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate, which in turn inhibits aconitase, causing citrate to accumulate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malonate - Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase, another enzyme in the TCA cycle, but it does not condense with oxaloacetate.

 

Option B. Arsenite - Arsenite inhibits the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, but it does not directly bind to CoA and condense with oxaloacetate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorocitrate is a potent inhibitor of aconitase, an enzyme in the TCA cycle, leading to the inhibition of the cycle and disruption of cellular energy metabolism.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p161-167

questions.text: During the Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle, citrate undergoes a series of transformations to facilitate cellular energy production. One of the initial steps involves the conversion of citrate to cis-aconitate. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme aconitase. Understanding the specific changes that occur during this conversion is essential for comprehending the intricate details of the TCA cycle. What is liberated during the conversion of citrate to cis-aconitate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) H2O.

 

Option A:

 

The conversion of citrate to cis-aconitate, catalyzed by aconitase, involves the removal of a water molecule (dehydration). This is an intermediary step before cis-aconitate is hydrated back to form isocitrate, another compound in the TCA cycle. Therefore, H2O is liberated during this conversion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H2 - Hydrogen gas is not a product of this specific reaction in the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. H2O2 - Hydrogen peroxide is not produced during the conversion of citrate to cis-aconitate.

 

Option D. CO2 - Carbon dioxide is not liberated in this step; it is produced in later steps of the TCA cycle when isocitrate and then alpha-ketoglutarate are decarboxylated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Citrate isomerized to Isocitrate by Aconitase which is a reversible reaction.
  • The reaction occurs in two steps: dehydration to cis aconitate and rehydration to isocitrate.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p163

questions.text: A 2-months-old male infant presents with seizures, hypotonia, retardation of psychomotor functions and poor head control. Blood investigations show lactic acidosis and highly elevated plasma pyruvate levels, which are several times higher than the normal level. When the Pyruvate carboxylase activity was measured using the fibroblasts extracts, it is less than 1 percent of the normal level. Administration of which of the following amino acids would be the best therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamine

 

Option B:

 

Glutamine administration is beneficial in conditions with pyruvate carboxylase deficiency. Glutamine can contribute to anaplerosis, replenishing the TCA cycle intermediates, thus helping to mitigate the effects of the enzyme deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Alanine - Not directly useful in replenishing TCA cycle intermediates in the context of pyruvate carboxylase deficiency.

 

Option C: Leucine - An essential amino acid but not specifically beneficial for treating pyruvate carboxylase deficiency.

 

Option D: Lysine - Essential but does not have a direct role in ameliorating the effects of pyruvate carboxylase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Deficiency in pyruvate carboxylase leads to diminution of oxaloacetate, a C4 acid which acts as an acceptor for the acetyl group from acetyl-CoA.
  • For the TCA cycle to function efficiently, C4 acids must be replenished by feeding the TCA with carbon skeletons of amino acids.
  • Glutamine → converted to alpha-ketoglutarate → increase in all of C4 acids (succinate, fumarate, malate, and oxaloacetate).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 164,165,188.

questions.text: A third-year medical student is shadowing in the metabolic diseases unit and encounters a patient being evaluated for a disorder affecting energy production. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of a defect in the complete oxidation of glucose. Intrigued, the student reviews biochemistry notes to understand where in the cell this process might be impaired. To aid in diagnosing and managing the patient's condition, the student seeks to identify the cellular compartment responsible for the full catabolism of glucose into carbon dioxide and water. Where are the enzymes located that facilitate this complete metabolic breakdown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitochondria

 

Option B:

 

Mitochondria are the organelles where complete oxidation of glucose occurs. Glycolysis happens in the cytosol, breaking glucose down into pyruvate, which then enters the mitochondria. Here, pyruvate undergoes further oxidation in the citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, resulting in the production of CO2, water, and ATP, the cell's energy currency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cytosol: Only hosts glycolysis, the first stage of glucose metabolism, not its complete oxidation.

 

Option C. Lysosomes: Involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, not in energy metabolism.

 

Option D. Endoplasmic reticulum: Plays a key role in protein and lipid synthesis, but not in the oxidation of glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is taken up into mitochondria and after oxidative decarboxylation to Acetyl-CoA is oxidized to CO2 by the citric acid cycle
  • Under anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is reduced by the NADH to lactate, catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p: 172

questions.text: A post-operative patient develops angular stomatitis and shows low riboflavin excretion, indicative of a deficiency. Riboflavin is essential for FAD, a coenzyme in the TCA cycle. Which TCA cycle enzyme, dependent on FAD, would be affected by this deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Succinate dehydrogenase

 

Option D:

 

  • The patient has demonstrated a deficiency in riboflavin (urinary excretion << 30 µg/mg creatinine is considered as clinically deficient).
  • Riboflavin is a component of the cofactor FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide) and is required for the conversion of succinate to fumarate by succinate dehydrogenase.

 

FAD-DEPENDENT ENZYMES:

 

  • Succinate to fumarate by succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Acyl CoA to alpha-beta unsaturated acyl CoA by acyl CoA dehydrogenase.
  • Xanthine to uric acid by xanthine oxidase
  • Pyruvate to acetyl CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA by alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Forms Alpha Keto Glutarate in TCA cycle with NADH generation, which is later oxidized in ETC to generate ATPs.

 

Option B.  Fumarase: In TCA cycle, it helps in formation of malate from fumarate and the reaction involves addition of a water molecule.

 

Option C. Malate dehydrogenase: In TCA cycle, malate is oxidized to oxaloacetate by this enzyme and the coenzyme is NAD+.

Note - None of the above 3 enzymes are dependent on FAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Succinate dehydrogenase is the TCA cycle enzyme directly impacted by riboflavin deficiency, as it uses FAD, derived from riboflavin, as a coenzyme. This enzyme catalyzes the oxidation of succinate to fumarate, with FAD being reduced to FADH2 in the process. A deficiency in riboflavin would impair the function of succinate dehydrogenase, affecting the efficiency of the TCA cycle and overall energy production.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 556; Vasudevan 9/e: 479.

questions.text: Among the following, which is NOT a function or significance of the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Synthesis of NADPH

 

Explanation

 

The synthesis of NADPH is NOT a function of the TCA cycle. The TCA cycle (tricarboxylic acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle or citric acid cycle) produces NADH, not NADPH. This is a key distinction because NADH and NADPH have different roles in metabolism:

  • NADH primarily serves as an electron carrier for energy production in the electron transport chain
  • NADPH serves as a reducing agent for biosynthetic reactions and antioxidant defense

 

The TCA cycle specifically generates reduced electron carriers in the form of NADH (three molecules per acetyl-CoA) and FADH₂ (one molecule per acetyl-CoA), but not NADPH. NADPH is primarily produced by other pathways such as:

  1. The pentose phosphate pathway
  2. The malic enzyme reaction
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase in the cytosol (not the mitochondrial form involved in the TCA cycle)
  4. NADP⁺-dependent glutamate dehydrogenase
  5. NADP⁺-dependent malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete oxidation of acetyl CoA - This IS a function of the TCA cycle. The cycle completely oxidizes the two-carbon acetyl group of acetyl-CoA to two molecules of CO₂. This oxidation is coupled with the reduction of electron carriers (NAD⁺ to NADH and FAD to FADH₂).

 

Option B. ATP generation - This IS a function of the TCA cycle. The cycle directly generates one GTP (equivalent to one ATP) per turn through substrate-level phosphorylation catalyzed by succinyl-CoA synthetase. More importantly, it indirectly enables substantial ATP production by providing NADH and FADH₂ to the electron transport chain for oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option D. Amphibolic pathway - This IS a characteristic of the TCA cycle. The term "amphibolic" means the pathway serves both catabolic (breakdown) and anabolic (biosynthetic) functions. While the TCA cycle primarily functions in catabolism to generate energy, several of its intermediates serve as precursors for biosynthetic pathways, including:

  • Oxaloacetate and α-ketoglutarate for amino acid synthesis
  • Succinyl-CoA for heme synthesis
  • Citrate for fatty acid synthesis (after transport to the cytosol)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key functions and significance of the TCA cycle include:

  • Complete oxidation of acetyl-CoA to CO₂
  • Energy production through substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP) and generation of reducing equivalents (NADH, FADH₂)
  • Serving as a final common oxidative pathway for carbohydrates, proteins, and fats
  • Acting as an amphibolic pathway (both catabolic and anabolic functions)

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p161-167.

questions.text: While conducting a research study on the efficiency of various diets on long-distance runners, a team of exercise physiologists focuses on the metabolic pathways that are most active during extended periods of physical activity. They are particularly interested in quantifying the energy output from different substrates. The team debates the number of ATP molecules generated from the complete oxidation of one molecule of acetyl CoA through the TCA cycle. What is the correct ATP yield from this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  10 ATP

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

The oxidation of one molecule of acetyl CoA in the TCA cycle produces 3 NADH, 1 FADH2, and 1 GTP. With the assumption that 1 NADH generates 2.5 ATP and 1 FADH2 yields 1.5 ATP through oxidative phosphorylation, the total ATP produced is calculated as follows:

 

3 NADH x 2.5 ATP/NADH = 7.5 ATP

1 FADH2 x 1.5 ATP/FADH2 = 1.5 ATP

1 GTP = 1 ATP

 

The sum of these yields a total of 10 ATP per molecule of acetyl CoA oxidized through the TCA cycle, making option B the most accurate answer.

 

Note - Three molecules of NADH and one of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA catabolized in one turn of the cycle.

 

Educational Objective :

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 253.

questions.text: In conditions of low oxygen levels (low pO2), the body must adapt its metabolic pathways to ensure energy production continues. One such adaptation involves an enzyme that compensates for reduced Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle activity under hypoxic conditions. This enzyme facilitates a key step in an alternative pathway, allowing cells to generate ATP anaerobically. Which enzyme is responsible for this compensatory mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactate dehydrogenase

 

Option C:

 

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to lactate in the anaerobic glycolysis pathway, compensating for low TCA cycle activity under conditions of low oxygen. This reaction allows for the continued production of ATP anaerobically and the regeneration of NAD+, essential for glycolysis to proceed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphofructokinase: This enzyme catalyzes an early step in glycolysis and is not directly involved in compensating for low TCA cycle activity.

 

Option B. Glucokinase: This enzyme acts in the initial step of glycolysis in liver cells, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, and is not a compensatory mechanism for low TCA activity.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This enzyme converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA for entry into the TCA cycle; its activity is reduced, not compensated for, under low oxygen conditions.

    

Educational Objective:

 

In the absence of mitochondria (Eg: RBC) and in hypoxic conditions, anaerobic glycolysis will be turned on where lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) will convert pyruvate to lactate.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 168-169.
